moves.1. e4: King's pawn opening.  Sicilian Defense.  Nimzovich-Rossolimo attack.  Constructive comments are welcome and encouraged.  I am always looking to improve my game.
moves.1... c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 e6 4. d4 Qb6 5: White's idea is to defend his bishop and exert even more control of the center.
moves.5... Nxd4 6. Be3 Nxf3+ 7. Qxf3 a6 8. Nc3: This move exchanges a bishop for a pawn with little compensation for white.  The knight gains an outpost, but is not centralized.
moves.8... axb5 9. Nxb5 d6 10. O-O Bd7 11. Qe2: Black begins an attack on white's queen-side pawns.
moves.23... c4 24. Qe2 c3 25. Qh5 Be3 26. Qf3: Looking to pin the bishop on the advance of the c-pawn.
moves.26... c2 27. h3: Giving an outlet for the King.
moves.27... Qc4: Breaking the pin on the Bishop.
moves.28. Kh2 c1=Q 29. Rxc1 Qxc1 30. h4 Rc8: At this point white could resign but decided to continue the fight gaining practice in a losing position.
moves.31. g3 Rc2+ 32. Kh3 h5: Threatening 33...Qh1 Mate.  Also deflecting white's queen... (edit 8/30 - Yes, thank you for the correction.  I noticed the defence of h1 by white's queen during the match, but forgot when doing the annotation)
moves.33. Qxh5 Qh1+ 34. Kg4 Qxe4+: Removing the e-pawn which protects from a check by black's rook...
